headline: Tesla board made $3 billion via stock awards that dwarfed tech peers
summary:
STORY: Tesla's board of directors has earned more than $3 billion through stock awards. 

That far exceeded the value of those given to peers at the biggest U.S. tech firms at the time they were paid.

That's according to an analysis performed for Reuters by compensation and governance specialist Equilar.

It found CEO Elon Musk's brother Kimbal has earned nearly $1 billion since 2004, based on the appreciated value of stock options held or liquidated.

And director Ira Ehrenpreis has collected $869 million since 2007.

Board chair Robyn Denholm has made $650 million since 2014.

Directors reaped such windfalls even though they haven't awarded themselves new stock grants in five years.

The board agreed to suspend director compensation starting in 2021 to settle a shareholder lawsuit alleging excessive board-member pay.

But between 2018 and 2020 the average Tesla director received a total of about $12 million in cash-and-stock compensation.

That was about eight times as much as the average director at Alphabet, the next highest-paid among the "Magnificent Seven" companies over the same period.

The value of those original awards skyrocketed along with Tesla's share price in subsequent years.

The analysis shows Tesla is the only company among that cohort where the size of directors' original stock awards played such an outsized role in the vast wealth they've earned from their part-time jobs.

content.title: Tesla board made $3 billion via stock awards that dwarfed tech peers

headline: Wall Street Has Lots of Questions. Stock Markets Might Not Like the Answers They Get This Week.
summary: Wall Street could find answers to some of its most important questions over the next five days as the final full trading week of a difficult year looks set to provide key tests to narratives about the economy, artificial- intelligence stocks, and the path of the Federal Reserve’s interest rate policy.  Investors enter the week, which typically marks the start of a traditional late-December rally, in a cautiously optimistic mood, with market volatility gauges ticking higher and benchmark  Treasury bond  yields trading north of levels seen prior to last week’s interest-rate cut by the U.S. central bank.  Megacap tech stocks also are on the back foot, with declines this month for every member of the so-called Magnificent 7 cohort apart from  Tesla  and big late-week declines for  Oracle  and  Broadcom  following mixed quarterly earnings updates that added to concerns over near-term profitability.

content.title: Wall Street Has Lots of Questions. Stock Markets Might Not Like the Answers They Get This Week.
content.summary: Wall Street could find answers to some of its most important questions over the next five days as the final full trading week of a difficult year looks set to provide key tests to narratives about the economy, artificial- intelligence stocks, and the path of the Federal Reserve’s interest rate policy.  Investors enter the week, which typically marks the start of a traditional late-December rally, in a cautiously optimistic mood, with market volatility gauges ticking higher and benchmark  Treasury bond  yields trading north of levels seen prior to last week’s interest-rate cut by the U.S. central bank.  Megacap tech stocks also are on the back foot, with declines this month for every member of the so-called Magnificent 7 cohort apart from  Tesla  and big late-week declines for  Oracle  and  Broadcom  following mixed quarterly earnings updates that added to concerns over near-term profitability.

headline: Tesla Owner Regrets Thinking His EV Was An 'Investment'—Says He's 'Genuinely Shocked At How Much These Things Are Tanking' After Losing $750 A Month
summary: It started with good intentions and a bit of EV hype. A Tesla Model Y buyer, now two and a half years into ownership, says he thought he was making a smart financial move. What he got, in his words, was a financial "bloodbath." In a post on Reddit, the owner of a 2022 Model Y Long Range said he paid $62,990 for the vehicle at peak EV prices. Fast forward to late 2025, and resale estimates from Carvana $36,800, CarMax $37,200, and Tesla's own trade-in $35,500 suggest a loss of $22,000 to $27,000—

content.title: Tesla Owner Regrets Thinking His EV Was An 'Investment'—Says He's 'Genuinely Shocked At How Much These Things Are Tanking' After Losing $750 A Month
content.summary: It started with good intentions and a bit of EV hype. A Tesla Model Y buyer, now two and a half years into ownership, says he thought he was making a smart financial move. What he got, in his words, was a financial "bloodbath." In a post on Reddit, the owner of a 2022 Model Y Long Range said he paid $62,990 for the vehicle at peak EV prices. Fast forward to late 2025, and resale estimates from Carvana $36,800, CarMax $37,200, and Tesla's own trade-in $35,500 suggest a loss of $22,000 to $27,000—

headline: Tesla shares jump as Musk confirms driverless robotaxi testing
summary: Tesla shares hit their highest in nearly a year on Monday after CEO Elon Musk said the ​electric-vehicle maker was testing its robotaxis without safety monitors in the ‌front passenger seat.  While much of Tesla's $1.53 trillion valuation — the highest of any automaker globally — is ‌tied to investor optimism around its self-driving technology and humanoid robot ambitions, the bulk of its revenue and profit still comes from selling electric vehicles.  Tesla launched a limited robotaxi service in Austin, Texas, in June using modified Model Y vehicles equipped with Full Self-Driving.

content.title: Tesla shares jump as Musk confirms driverless robotaxi testing
content.summary: Tesla shares hit their highest in nearly a year on Monday after CEO Elon Musk said the ​electric-vehicle maker was testing its robotaxis without safety monitors in the ‌front passenger seat.  While much of Tesla's $1.53 trillion valuation — the highest of any automaker globally — is ‌tied to investor optimism around its self-driving technology and humanoid robot ambitions, the bulk of its revenue and profit still comes from selling electric vehicles.  Tesla launched a limited robotaxi service in Austin, Texas, in June using modified Model Y vehicles equipped with Full Self-Driving.

headline: Tesla stock hits all-time high amid driverless robotaxi tests
summary: Tesla stock (TSLA) briefly hit a new record high in Monday's trading session after the EV maker announced that it is continuing to test its robotaxi services without a safety driver in Austin, Texas. Yahoo Finance senior autos reporter Pras Subramanian comes on Market Domination to further discuss the latest developments around the car company's automated vehicle plans. Also catch Yahoo Finance's interview with University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign associate professor Katherine Driggs-Campbell about the recent behavior shifts in autonomous vehicles' driving habits To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

content.title: Tesla stock hits all-time high amid driverless robotaxi tests
content.description:
Tesla stock (TSLA) briefly hit a new record high in Monday's trading session after the EV maker announced that it is continuing to test its robotaxi services without a safety driver in Austin, Texas.

Yahoo Finance senior autos reporter Pras Subramanian comes on Market Domination to further discuss the latest developments around the car company's automated vehicle plans.

Also catch Yahoo Finance's interview with University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign associate professor Katherine Driggs-Campbell about the recent behavior shifts in autonomous vehicles' driving habits

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.
content.summary: Tesla stock (TSLA) briefly hit a new record high in Monday's trading session after the EV maker announced that it is continuing to test its robotaxi services without a safety driver in Austin, Texas. Yahoo Finance senior autos reporter Pras Subramanian comes on Market Domination to further discuss the latest developments around the car company's automated vehicle plans. Also catch Yahoo Finance's interview with University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign associate professor Katherine Driggs-Campbell about the recent behavior shifts in autonomous vehicles' driving habits To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

headline: Ford is starting a battery storage business to power data centers and the grid
summary: Amid Ford’s shift away from making large electric vehicles, the automaker is adding a new product line to find a home for its batteries. Ford said Monday that instead of scuttling plans to build the batteries for those vehicles, it will pivot that capacity into a new battery storage business. Those storage systems, which will use cheaper LFP batteries, will be […]
